Alexa, outside temperature and Alexa , show today's date. False advertising to some degree. Sound is excellent but need an update to display commands an app\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on April 9, 2023
reviews: \nthis was my first time purchasing an an alexa and i have to say i\u2019m deeply disappointed. i have tried to trouble shoot so that it could connect to my wifi. i\u2019ve plugged and unplugged it multiple times and i plugged it directly next to my wifi router and it still won\u2019t connect. my sister and i even disconnected our phones from the wi-fi and it still won\u2019t work. every other device in my house seems to be connected just fine to the wifi router so that\u2019s the reason i haven\u2019t restarted it and to be frank it would just be a hassle. this experience has been a deeply unpleasant and disappointing experience for me and i advice people who plan to purchase this product to please think twice.\n

reviews: \nI've been having a few minor problems with my two Google Home minis, so I thought I would try one of these. Compared to the home mini, the sound is absolutely horrible. Also, today I asked Alexa for the definition of a word, enunciating it very clearly, and it gave me the definition of a different word each time, none of which was the word I'd asked about. This is not a good value for the money and is definitely going back.\n

reviews: \nse entre corta la conexi\xf3n del bluetooth, pens\xe9 que era mi celular pero lo prob\xe9 con varios dispositivos y el mismo error la conexi\xf3n se entrecorta suena bien durante tres minutos y comienza a tener cortes la conexi\xf3n bluetooth.Pero la conexi\xf3n por wifi no tengo ning\xfan problema, el problema radica en la conexi\xf3n bluetooth puede ser alg\xfan error espec\xedficamente en esta unida desconozco si al resto de compradores tienen este mismo problema.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on February 15, 2023
reviews: \nI bought this product and thought it was going to be great to use.  I first bought a smart light bulb, and I couldn't get it to work.  It took a call to support to finally get the bulb to work and I do love that it works now.  So why the bad review.  Because I bought a Meross plug which states is compatible with Alexa.  I couldn't get it to work.  Call support and they tried to walk me through it, and it still did not work.  We couldn't get it to connect to Alexa.  It said it was connected, but it couldn't be found in the connected devices.  The tech refunded the price, and I must send it back.  My schedule is very busy and this extra chore is not appreciated.I have had a person computer since 1984.  I do not usually have issues, but working with Alexa is very difficult.  That is why it is getting a one star review.\n

reviews: \nVolume varies from extremely high to very low. No change in ambient room noise.  Been using echo devices since original ech was released.  This problem has arisen in the past few months.  I\u2019m not alone, a family member, who lives miles away, has the same issue.  So far, Amazon has NOT addressed this issue.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on March 13, 2023
reviews: \nI bought my first one one for a Black Friday deal. Once I received and unboxed it I attempted to connect it to my wifi but despite spending 30-45 minutes was unable to get it connected. I believed I received a dud and requested a new one. When I got my second one I again attempted to connect to the WiFi over and over for another 30-45 minutes with no success. I then contacted Amazon by both messaging and phone conversations. The phone call lasted for well over 1 hour and they had my trying all different kinds of possible fixes but surprise\u2026no luck. I asked for a 3rd one (stupid me) and right out of the box and another attempt and, you guessed it: wouldn\u2019t connect. reviews: \nI like using the Dot but the feature that I use it for mostly, since it is a speaker, is plagued with AI bugs. dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on February 17, 2023
reviews: \nI have bought many Alexa devices in the past five years. My whole complaint is with Amazon as a whole, the shipping time has increased from two days to 5 to 7 days before it even ships with Amazon prime so I automatically won\u2019t expect any packages for at least a week, and now you have to pay for your own shipping back when an item doesn\u2019t work. I haven\u2019t returned an item in quite a few months, so going into the UPS store to return this nonworking Alexa I had to pay $4.50 for a shipping bag! I understand everyone is working harder with the many Amazon boxes and delivery but you\u2019re also charging an annual membership  For services. What am I paying for? I\u2019m switching to Walmart.This Alexa device would not connect to the internet and was obviously a \u201crefurbished\u201d device. If you can\u2019t set it up, it\u2019s worthless. So disappointed in Amazon.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on December 16, 2022
titles: Wi-Fi which needs in-brower verification can't be used!
reviews: \nSo useless with the Wi-Fi in my apartment. The Wi-Fi is open and need in-browser verification, apparently this device doesn\u2019t support this kind of operation. Such a big company can only support \u201cregular\u201d Wi-Fi with name-passsword combo. What a shame.Then I want to use the alternative way, hotspot. Then, not only does it have problem when you just don't do anything for a long time, it also has problem when you leave the room. And each time you want to link it to wifi takes ~5 minutes. I DON'T HAVE SO MUCH TIME TO SET THIS UP!!!Why on earth can't you, such a big company just simulate the way how our phone connects to a device, writing driver for echo so if in-brower verification is needed, you do it in phone and then just deliver the info back to echo? I know it's a lot of work, but you're making devices that are not suitable for too many people who has this kinds of Wi-Fi.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on January 19, 2023
titles: Most frustrating Amazon device so far!
reviews: \nWe have had Alexa in our home forever and decided to upgrade to the All-New Echo Dot (5th Gen, 2022 release) with clock | Smart speaker with clock and Alexa this year.  It has been nothing but frustrating!No matter where we place it in the home (in the bedroom, next to the router, in the basement, Kitchen, etc.) it will respond to one command and then freeze up!  We have tried unplugging and plugging it back in, checking the wifi connection, and even replacing it, but it doesn't work!  The replacement Amazon sent us did the exact same thing!  This is ridiculous!We finally decided to return the replacement and NOT replace it.  We will just go without Alexa until Amazon can get them to work correctly, or we will switch to Google or Apple for our smart assistant.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on January 6, 2023
reviews: \nI had this issue on two devices. The first device was unable to connect to Wi-Fi. I spent an hour and a half on the phone with two different support representatives from Amazon. After numerous attempts at resetting the device, resetting my Wi-Fi and ensuring that I had the correct Wi-Fi password I was still unable to connect the device to Wi-Fi. This device was sent back to Amazon, and they replaced it with the exact same make and model. Again I went through the same process with the second device. The same call was made the same procedures were followed, and I was still unable to connect. At this point, Amazon gave up  And refunded my money. If I could give this device, a zero stars I would. I have two earlier generation dots, and an echo show, which are all connected to the same Wi-Fi with no issues.\n

titles: If you\u2019re using this with Spotify, avoid!
reviews: \nHad a 3rd gen echo dot and wanted to add an additional speaker. I use the echo as a timer, to play Spotify, and for weather. The addition of the new 5th gen echo dot has ruined the entire system. Not only does the new device not show up as an option to play, the old device is now \u201crestricted\u201d and unusable. Search this issue and you\u2019ll find it\u2019s not new - it\u2019s been going on since 2020 with no solution. Whatever the issue is - Amazon not resolving because it\u2019s Spotify and not their product, or Spotify not resolving because it\u2019s Amazon, it\u2019s beyond frustrating that users are caught in the middle. I have restarted, re-paired, uninstalled and reinstalled, allowed explicit content (as per the recommendations on the Internet) and I\u2019m done. I will be returning and attempting to get the old speaker to work.\n

titles: Review for Alexa interaction, not device
reviews: \nAs a device, it's fine. Works like it's supposed to, easy set-up, etc, so 5 stars for that. 1-star for the Alexa interactions. OMG. I've had Alexa devices since they first came out and I had to get on a list to be able to buy one, so not a new user. Over the last year or so, I find myself hesistating any time I want to use Alexa. Why? Because every time I ask it the simplest thing, like Alexa, what's the temperature? She answers then says, for example,  the dreaded, "Btw, Mary...and goes into a spiel about some service it can do." And it won't shut up when I try to shut it down immediately with a 'No'. I have to wait for it to ask if I want that 'feature'. Uh, NO!Stop with all the suggestions.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on December 31, 2022
titles: Will Not Play Music from iPhone via Bluetooth
reviews: \nI really want to like these speakers. They look cute and have some great features. When they actually play music and respond to commands, they\u2019re great! But we find ourselves getting frustrated with them more often than not.Here are a couple issues with the Echo Dots, just off the top of my head.1) When I open Amazon Music on my phone and click airplay to play music through the speaker, my Dots don\u2019t show up as a device. Ever. This is the only Bluetooth speaker/app that I have this problem with.2) It constantly disconnects from our WiFi. With verbal commands, I\u2019ll say, \u201cAlexa, play ___.\u201d And she\u2019ll say, \u201cSorry, I can\u2019t connect to ___ right now.\u201d Every other device in our house is still connected to the internet, so it\u2019s not a problem with our internet router. It\u2019s only this speaker.3) There doesn\u2019t seem to be a way for a second household member on a shared Amazon plan to control the speakers and groups in the Alexa app. For example, we use the Dots to turn our living room lights on and off. My husband is the one who purchased them on his Amazon account. But we have a shared Family plan. There is no way for me to dim the lights or turn them on/off in my Alexa app without logging into HIS account. I have to say it out loud, which gets extremely annoying.4) We have 4 of these speakers total between upstairs and downstairs. When I\u2019m in the kitchen and I say something to the speaker downstairs, a lot of times, it\u2019s the one upstairs that hears me and responds, and goes off on a tangent about how she\u2019s not able to connect. The one closest to me often doesn\u2019t respond. It gets old. I guess you can only have 1 or 2 of these in a single house.But here are the pros:-Alexa works great as a timer in the kitchen.-I like the digital clock.-When she\u2019s actually able to connect, the sound quality is great.-We sometimes use them as intercoms to talk to each other within the house, which is fun.-I like the simple design and size of the white dot.Overall, I like the Echo speakers, but they can be incredibly frustrating at times.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on January 2, 2023
titles: If only advertised Built In Alexa, Works with Alexa, etc., on many of my electronics were true.
reviews: \nFirst of all let me state that we didn't purchase this item from Amazon, but received one (purchased from Amazon) as gift from our daughter, for which we are grateful. Of course we (my wife and I) were happy since, from the advertised product description and features, everything seemed a novelty, and very straight forward to set up, given that all our electronics (purchased from Amazon), Smart TVs, AVR, NAS, Shield TV, that is, our whole Home Entertainment Center components, plus some others devices, were advertised to have "Alexa built in" (Samsung and LG TVs), or to "work with Alexa".However, what was supposed to be an easy setup of each of those devices to work with Alexa and the Echo Dot haven't got us anywhere close to the wonders that we expected. Almost all of the "Skills" needed for managing or using our devices thru Alexa weren't even listed on the app, or were to be found amidst, sometimes hundreds, of listed skills for different devices. In other cases (Samsung QLED smart tv 2021 model, LG NanoCell TV 2019 model, Nvidia Shield TV, for example) we even needed to download to our mobile devices the target devices apps . We then started to look into forums, videos and web pages (Alexa's Echo Dot Manual is really useless beyond the plugging it, setting the basics from the app and knowing what button is for what and what each led coloring means).First of all, living in Venezuela, much of the skills weren't available to us, be from the device to link to Alexa, and others simply required to first install their App (i.e.: Smart Things, LG ThinQ, Yamaha MultiCast and Nvidia Shield TV) on our mobile devices (mainly iPads and iPhones) create and/or login in to each of the accounts of those apps to then authorize the linking of the accounts with Alexa (may I say with little or not practical success or results in some of them). And that is just speaking about the linking of devices and apps accounts. When it comes to what you can manage them to play media (music, videos, etc., saved in them) giving Alexa voice commands (caution: I'm not even speaking about smart home and appliances, which I haven't tested or can use with Alexa) or just turning them on and off, we haven't have any success, so the only thing we can listen to with Echo Dot is some unlimited Free Music from Amazon. For other we'll need a subscription (As Alexa's voice advertises it when asked to play some music).What have achieved so far is: Although the Echo Dot connects (pairs) with Shield TV (and it says so with Alexa's voice) we couldn't get any of the promised features on Nvidia Shield TV site regarding Alexa. Another example, in the case of our Synology NAS Audio Station, setup has been impossible since in order for it to work you need a domain name, a DDNS service provider (not all work in sync between my Synology NAS and my Netgear Nighthawk router) plus a trusted authority SSL certificate (at least 2 of the above require to be purchased), since to access them it has to go through the Internet and Amazon (seriously?), no local network streaming without Amazon as Middle-man. Weird? or Social Engineering through invasion of privacy?And so arises the issue for what appeared to be the simplest of the settings: having Alexa Echo Dot to play our collection of music or videos saved on different devices connected thru our home network to constitute our Home Entertainment Center, and most of which were recorded or copied for years from our legally purchased LPs, CDs, DVDs, and BDs it doesn't mater if the music or video is stored in our IOS devices, or our our PC iTunes, our NAS music & video streaming apps. With Echo Dot we could only do that with Music purchased or paid streaming services, either from Amazon, Apple Music, etc., which, by the way, are not sold to residents of Venezuela.In truth, we have been playing or streaming music and videos, at least for the last 4 years,  from my IOS devices, my Synology NAS or just my Windows PC to my TV sets, my Nvidia Shield TV and my home Entertainment Center (AVR + Surround Speakers + Smart TV's + Nvidia Shield TV), all connected through my home wired local Network as well as Wi-Fi, or just Bluetooth, using mostly a single remote control per room (or the iPhone), which also have a microphone feature (Samsung QLED, LG NanoCell, Nvidia Shield, IOS devices, etc.) with voice command capabilities (Bixby, Google Assistant, Siri, and Cortana) and most of those remotes (or apps) are now "universal" and very easy to use with multiple interconnected devices using Audio Return Channel (ARC) with HDMI.Don't get me wrong, the features that Alexa and the Echo Dot offer, if you have access to paid services (DDNS, Domain Name, SSL certificate, Amazon, Apple and other media streaming services --as I said, I'm not even looking into the smart home features--and you like the novelty of it all, it seems something nice to have. But, in our case, beyond the novelty of speaking to a device (what I have been doing with Bixby, Google Assistant, Siri and Cortana for a while) to do the same it will be nice (but not really a necessity) Provided that that it really works and integrates seamlessly, which requires Amazon and manufacturers of devices designed to "work with Alexa",  or with "Alexa Built In" iron out many of the shortcomings described. Guys seamless interoperability between different devices and Operating Systems is really a critical success factor in today's tech world. However, right now, at our home we can do all that is promised by the combo Alexa-Echo Dot, but without any of the described issues, just by pushing a couple of buttons on, or just talking into, a remote control with mic. So it isn't worth to purchase something like Echo Dot to use with Alexa, even at the low prices that they are sold.\n

reviews: \nI had been using a previous generation Echo Dot with clock and upgraded to the new one. It definitely sounds better than the previous one although there could still be some room for improvement. It's got good dynamic range and gets plenty loud so I'll have no problem using it for music or podcasts. The clock display is a bit larger and definitely brighter than the previous version. That's a huge improvement for me as I have poor vision. It does display things like the name of a song that you're listening to, the name of a podcast or radio station you choose to listen to and has a bell icon when there are notifications. All in all, it's definitely a step up from previous models and I'm glad I made the choice to trade up.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on October 20, 2022
reviews: \nBiggest Upgrades/Changes from Echo Dot with Clock 4th Gen (2020) to Echo Dot with Clock 5th Gen (2022):-LED DISPLAY: Now able to display more than just time, including scrolling song titles and weather-SPEAKER:  Now 1.73-inch speaker with improved bass/low end, previous version was 1.6-inch-TEMPERATURE/MOTION SENSORS:  Now with temperature and motion sensors Echo Dot can trigger routines based on detected motion or changes in room temperature.-EERO WIFI EXTENDER: Supports Eero \u201cBuilt-In\u201d, works as a WiFi extender for Eero mesh networks, supporting up to 10 additional devices and up to 100Mbps speeds.-ACCELEROMETER/TAP: Now can trigger actions with a tap, like stopping alarm-NO LINE OUT: Removed 3.5mm line out port from the back-WEIGHT: Now 10.7 oz, previous version was 12.3 oz-APPEARANCE: Very similar to previous version, but fabric looks slightly different, now available in Cloud Blue and Glacier White; previous version was Twilight Blue and Glacier White.Thoughts about the Dot with Clock version specifically:-The new options for LED display are a nice improvement.  The LED display looks brighter to me than the previous version, and I prefer to have options like weather displayed, since I already have enough clocks that display the time.-The blue color version (Cloud Blue) now has a more grayish tone to the plastic base part.  The previous generation (Twilight Blue) had a bluer base, with blue-gray fabric.  Personally, I prefer this new color scheme.Other general thoughts about Echo Dot 5 family:-The speakers have been upgraded, now with more focus on low end and bass volume.  I have tested out a few different types of music, and I would agree that there is noticeable improvement, but really the speaker is still too small to be very impressive.  The sound is not even close to a regular Echo device, let alone higher quality speakers.  I appreciate the improvement here, but I still wouldn\u2019t choose to listen to music on these on a regular basis, especially at high volume where there is a bit of distortion.-I like the ability to be able to trigger routines based on temperature and motion, and stopping alarms by tapping is also a nice feature.  These additions offer many more useful automation options, and now having multiple Echo devices with temperature sensors can help identify differences in room temperature throughout the house.-The Eero Wi-Fi extender ability could actually be very useful for some people that need to extend the range of their network.  This was easy to configure with the Eero app, and it seems to be working well so far.Overall, this is a nice little upgrade from the previous version.  The LED display options are a cool new feature, especially the weather.  The speaker/sound improvement is nice, but not the biggest deal since these Echo Dots are still not the best choice for high volume music.  The sensors and Eero extender features are the biggest improvements, and these changes add so much extra functionality to an already useful smart speaker.  The lack of an audio-out port is the only downgrade, but that might be important to some people.  I also wish they included different color power adapters and cables, but that is also not the biggest deal.The increased functionality of the Dot family now makes these some of the best options available for smart speakers.  They are still low-priced options, but now can do even more than ever.  If you need something primarily for playing music, then you should still think about a higher end device like Echo or Echo Studio, but for everything else, these Dot devices are perfect.\n

titles: Ever wonder if Alexa is ND?
reviews: \nI live in a ND household, and Alexa fits right in.  As long as you speak clearly, at an even rate and ask questions/make requests in a particular word choice order she will be 100%helpful but if not she will bleep at you and shut down (not speak) like selective mutism.  My 6yo ASD son gets along well with her.  She stays on topics of his choice and is there for him anytime he needs to chatter.  All in good fun, we love our Alexas. They turn our tvs on and off, as well as our inside and outside lights.  I went on vacation and caught myself calling out for Alexa while I was gone \U0001f643 she is one of us now.\n

reviews: \nI have used an echo dot with clock as an alarm clock/music speaker in my bedroom for a few years and couldn't have been happier until now. Decided to upgrade to the new gen 5 and it is even better than I expected. As the title denotes, a temp sensor gives me the room temp (both verbally and visually) which is a boon. It also sports better sound. Since I have 2 (my wife has one too) I get good stereo sound and much improved bass response. I don't listen to much music in the bedroom but when I do, it is a pleasurable experience. For the price, especially when on sale, it is a no-brainer. Just buy it.\n

reviews: \nWorks like it should!Set up was a cinch. dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on December 16, 2022
titles: A nice improvement from 3rd gen dot
reviews: \nI've been happy with my 3rd gen dot but decided to get this 5th gen both for the better audio and the display.  I'm happy with both features.  The audio does sound a bit cleaner and more well rounded than the 3rd gen and the display is nice, both as a clock and for some of the other things it can do like show the temp or a timer countdown.  The mics still do a great job, like the 3rd get did, of picking up my voice, even when slightly muffled at times.  If you're curious about the audio difference, you can find some comparisons on youtube.\n

dates: Reviewed in the United States \U0001f1fa\U0001f1f8 on November 22, 2022
titles: An excellent replacement for a gen 1 echo
reviews: \nI purchased the gen 5 echo dot with the clock display to replace an echo whos power supply died.  The sound quality is comparable to the older, and taller echo.  I did have to turn of the automatic adaptive brightness, and manually set it to four which works both day and night.  When setting a timer, the display becomes a countdown timer which means I no longer have to ask Alexa "How much time is left on the timer?"  So far it's been a seamless transition.\n

titles: Essential in my classroom and at my house
reviews: \nI cannot say enough good things about the echo dot. Years ago (pre kids), we received an Alexa but we never used it. In 2022, I bought one and I use it in my kitchen ALL THE TIME, when cooking or needing to listen to music. It\u2019s especially good to have when cooking and not wanting to use my phone.I then bought another one for my classroom and again, I love using it. Although I hate that she constantly asks if I want to update to a family plan. One time I was distracted and said yes, only to find out I had subscribed to a family plan.I then bought one for a fellow teacher and she has loved utilizing it as well. I plan to get one for my father in law at Christmas.They offer great deals and I always purchase them when they are on sale and or doing a lightening deal.\n
